data.text: @trains_for_kids @paul_bower @GWRHelp @AvantiWestCoast @NetworkRailEUS You know what's really family friendly, telling travelers what platform the trains leave from on advance. In Europe they tell you days in advance.

@paul_bower @PhinHarper At Paddington @GWRHelp have introduced a priority boarding service for families to have a little extra time and help getting on the train. We'd love to see @AvantiWestCoast do something similar at @NetworkRailEUS.

https://t.co/MwBUoixiAD

@PhinHarper Itâ€™s so uncivilised. I saw desperate mums with prams running, what happens to those who cannot run? We had to squeeze into a packed train to get back to London from Coventry as trains were being cancelled, standing all the way, amongst us an elderly man on clutches.
@paul_bower @PhinHarper Surely to prevent congestion at gates. If you ask they tell you though in advance of it appearing.
@paul_bower Traveling in Europe, the platforms are often labeled on your ticket or in the train company's app. Here, they keep us guessing.
@TomHainesDoran @paul_bower Not in my experience. But they are not exactly a paragon of best practice so we probably shouldn't copy them if so!
@Clivedurdle @paul_bower @PhinHarper I wasn't commenting on whether it was justified or not
